learning_outcomes.description: Logic Objectives - Explain the nature of formal logical systems, and the distinction between their syntax and semantics.
Logic Objectives - Work comfortably with the concepts of proof and validity and relatedsyntactic and semantic notions.
Logic Objectives - Explain the relationship of formal mathematical theories (such asarithmetic) to general logical systems.
Logic Objectives - Describe the possibility of extensions of these systems into non-standard mathematical theories.
Logic Objectives - Describe the various limit results on mathematical and other logicalsystems such as the undecidability and incompleteness theorems.
Logic Objectives - Describe the relationships between different models of algorithms and computability, and how they relate to the incompleteness theorems.
Set Theory Objectives - Explain the paradoxes of naive set theory, and how they are resolved by axiomatizing set theory.
Set Theory Objectives - Learn the ZFC axioms of set theory.
Set Theory Objectives - Describe the definition/construction of all common mathematical objects (functions, relations, the real numbers etc) in terms of sets.
Set Theory Objectives - Explain the Axiom of Choice, and be able to construct proofs based on its formulation as Zorns Lemma.
Set Theory Objectives - Explain ordinal and cardinal numbers and their arithmetic.
Set Theory Objectives - Explain the Continuum Hypothesis and similar results.

assessments.task_description: This assignment requires you to answer the questions and submit your written solutions through Blackboard.
assessments.submission_guidelines: The assignment should be submitted through Blackboard.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description: The in-semester examination will be held in class, during the regular Tuesday lecture time.

assessments.task_description:
The final examination in this course will be held during the end-of-semester examination period. It will be an in-person exam held on campus.

The final exam will cover material from the entire course.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Revision week(22 Jul - 03 Nov)
learning_activities.topic:
Reading and homework problems

Before and after each lecture and tutorial you are expected to be reading text and other suggested sources for deeper understanding of the material, and trying all homework problems set. This is essential to understand and pass this course -- lectures and tutes alone will not teach you everything you need to know, you are expected to be self-learners in this course.
